dictionary.definition: sharing a lot of similarities; seeming to have been created, reared, or fashioned in the same way. She and her brother are cut from the same cloth. They both tell lies all the time.  Father and son are made from the same mold and even sound alike on the telephone.

sharing a lot of similarities; seeming to have been created, reared, or fashioned in the same way. She and her brother are cut from the same cloth. They both tell lies all the time.  Father and son are made from the same mold and even sound alike on the telephone.

dictionary.phrase: cut one’s coat according to one’s cloth
dictionary.definition: Prov. to plan one’s aims and activities in line with one’s resources and circumstances.  We would like a bigger house, but we must cut our coat according to our cloth.  They can’t afford a vacation abroad—they have to cut their coat according to their cloth.

dictionary.phrase: cut one’s coat to suit one’s cloth
dictionary.definition: Prov. to plan one’s aims and activities in line with one’s resources and circumstances.  We would like a bigger house, but we must cut our coat according to our cloth.  They can’t afford a vacation abroad—they have to cut their coat according to their cloth.
to leave quickly for some place.  The kids all cut out for home. When they heard their mother call, the Wilson kids cut out for home.
to leave quickly for some place.  The kids all cut out for home. When they heard their mother call, the Wilson kids cut out for home.

Sl. to give someone a break; to allow someone a reprieve from the consequences of an action. Come on, cut me a break! I’m a good guy! _ I was only a few minutes late! Cut me a break! Don’t dock my pay! _ Cut me some slack and I’ll be sure to pay you all I owe in a month.

Sl. to give someone a break; to allow someone a reprieve from the consequences of an action. Come on, cut me a break! I’m a good guy! _ I was only a few minutes late! Cut me a break! Don’t dock my pay! _ Cut me some slack and I’ll be sure to pay you all I owe in a month.
to make a person humble; to put one in one’s place.  John’s critical remarks really cut me down to size.  Jane is too conceited. I think her new boss will take her down to size.
to make a person humble; to put one in one’s place.  John’s critical remarks really cut me down to size.  Jane is too conceited. I think her new boss will take her down to size.

dictionary.phrase: cut someone or something with something
dictionary.definition: to slice someone or something with or on something.  Don’t cut yourself on that sharp blade.  He cut the bread with a dull knife and crushed it.

dictionary.phrase: cut someone or something on something
dictionary.definition: to slice someone or something with or on something.  Don’t cut yourself on that sharp blade.  He cut the bread with a dull knife and crushed it.

to slice the flesh of someone or some animal clear through to the underlying layer of flesh or to the bone.  With the very sharp knife, David cut the beast to the quick in one blow.  He cut his finger to the quick with the sharp knife.

to slice the flesh of someone or some animal clear through to the underlying layer of flesh or to the bone.  With the very sharp knife, David cut the beast to the quick in one blow.  He cut his finger to the quick with the sharp knife.

to cut a pattern or shape from cloth, paper, sheet metal, etc.; to remove something from something by cutting; to excise something from something. (When both out and of are used, no direct object can intervene.) _Sam cut a pig out from the paper.  I cut the picture out of a magazine.  I cut out the shape of the moon from the paper.

to cut a pattern or shape from cloth, paper, sheet metal, etc.; to remove something from something by cutting; to excise something from something. Sl. to release intestinal gas. (Crude. Use caution with the topic.) _Who cut the cheese? _People who cut the mustard in the car have to get out and walk.

Stop acting silly and telling jokes!; Be serious! (Use shit with caution, as it is considered vulgar.) _ John: All right, you guys! Cut the comedy and get to work! Bill: Can’t we ever have any fun? John: No. Bill: Come on, Mary, let’s throw Tom in the pool! Mary: Yeah, let’s drag him over and give him a good dunking! Tom: Okay, you clowns, cut the funny stuff! I’ll throw both of you in!

to pat or wipe something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Please dab the butter off your chin. Please dab off the butter. Dab the moisture off of the apples.
to pat or wipe something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _Please dab the butter off your chin. Please dab off the butter. Dab the moisture off of the apples.
to pat or spread carefully something onto something else.  Dab some medicine onto the scratch.  Dab on some medicine.
to pat or spread carefully something onto something else.  Dab some medicine onto the scratch.  Dab on some medicine.
the biggest or oldest of all; the patriarch.  This old fish is the granddaddy of them all.  This tree is the daddy of them all. It’s been here since the place was built.

to shift quickly to different behavior; to change one’s behavior or attitude.  After being yelled at, Ann danced to another tune. A stern talking-to will make her dance to a different tune.

to tempt someone by dangling a tempting object in front of them.  Don’t dangle that string of pearls in front of me unless you intend to give them to me!

dictionary.phrase: dangle something in front of someone

dictionary.phrase: The darkest hour is just before the dawn.
dictionary.definition: Prov. When things are extremely bad, it may signal that they are about to get much better.  Jill: I feel like giving up. I don’t have a job, my boyfriend left me, and they’re raising the rent for my apartment. Jane: It’s always darkest just before the dawn.

dictionary.phrase: It’s always darkest just before the dawn.
dictionary.definition: Prov. When things are extremely bad, it may signal that they are about to get much better.  Jill: I feel like giving up. I don’t have a job, my boyfriend left me, and they’re raising the rent for my apartment. Jane: It’s always darkest just before the dawn.
absolutely. You’re darn tooting I’ll be there. I wouldn’t miss it for the world.
absolutely. You’re darn tooting I’ll be there. I wouldn’t miss it for the world.
to write a note or letter quickly and send it off.  I have to dash this letter off, then I will be with you.  I’ll dash off a note to her.
to write a note or letter quickly and send it off.  I have to dash this letter off, then I will be with you.  I’ll dash off a note to her.
to run away; to leave in a hurry. I must dash away. See you tomorrow. Juan had to dash away to an appointment.  Ken dashed off and left me behind to deal with the angry customer.

to smear or paint something onto something else.  The painter daubed a bit of yellow onto the canvas.  Daub on a bit of yellow here.  She daubed the medicine on.

all the time; around the clock.  The nurse was at her bedside day and night.  The house is guarded night and day.
all the time; around the clock.  The nurse was at her bedside day and night.  The house is guarded night and day.
on every day; for each day. She watches soap operas day in and day out.  They eat nothing but vegetables, day in, day out.
on every day; for each day. She watches soap operas day in and day out.  They eat nothing but vegetables, day in, day out.
days in a series; months in a series; etc. (Follows a number.) _ I had a bad cold for five days running.  For two years running, I brought work home from the office every night.

dead; no longer in existence. (*Also: as ~.) _ That silly old idea is dead as a dodo.  When I tried to start my car this morning, I discovered that the battery was deader than a doornail.
dead; no longer in existence. (*Also: as ~.) _ That silly old idea is dead as a dodo.  When I tried to start my car this morning, I discovered that the battery was deader than a doornail.
dead; no longer in existence. (*Also: as ~.) _ That silly old idea is dead as a dodo.  When I tried to start my car this morning, I discovered that the battery was deader than a doornail.
exhausted; worn out; no longer useful.  Ann is so tired. She’s really dead on her feet.  He can’t teach well anymore. He’s dead on his feet.  This inefficient company is dead on its feet.

to pass out cards to someone, making that person a player in a card game. Can you deal me into this hand? _Deal in anyone who wants to play.  Deal me in!

to skip someone when dealing a hand of cards.  Please deal me out of the next hand. I have to go make a telephone call.  They dealt out the old lady because she would not pay attention to the game.

dictionary.phrase: decide among someone and someone else
dictionary.definition: to choose from three or more people; to choose from three or more things.  I couldn’t decide among all the choices on the menu.  I will decide among Fred, Tom, and Alice.

dictionary.phrase: decide among something and something else
dictionary.definition: to choose from three or more people; to choose from three or more things.  I couldn’t decide among all the choices on the menu.  I will decide among Fred, Tom, and Alice.

dictionary.phrase: decide between someone and someone else
dictionary.definition: to choose one from two people; to choose one from two things. I could not decide between Tom and Wally. We could not decide between those two.

dictionary.phrase: decide between something and something else
dictionary.definition: to choose one from two people; to choose one from two things. I could not decide between Tom and Wally. We could not decide between those two.

dictionary.phrase: deck someone or something out† (in something)
dictionary.definition: to decorate someone or something with something. Sally decked all her children out for the holiday party. She decked out her children in Halloween costumes.  Tom decked the room out with garlands of f lowers.

dictionary.phrase: deck someone or something out (with something)
dictionary.definition: to decorate someone or something with something. Sally decked all her children out for the holiday party. She decked out her children in Halloween costumes.  Tom decked the room out with garlands of f lowers.

dictionary.phrase: declare war against someone or something
dictionary.definition: to formally announce that one will fight a war with someone or some country.  A group of countries declared war against the aggressor.

dictionary.phrase: declare war on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to formally announce that one will fight a war with someone or some country.  A group of countries declared war against the aggressor.
to decide that something is necessary.  Mary deemed that it was necessary to leave town that night.  Lisa deemed it necessary to go home.
to decide that something is necessary.  Mary deemed that it was necessary to leave town that night.  Lisa deemed it necessary to go home.
No, without any doubt at all. (Compare this with Absolutely not!) _Bill: Will you lend me some money? Bob: No way! Definitely not! _Bob: Have you ever stolen anything? Fred: Certainly not!

to think about someone or something; to consider what to do about someone or something. How long do you intend to deliberate about Carol? _We will deliberate about this matter as long as it takes to do it right.  Let’s deliberate on this for a while.

dictionary.phrase: demand something from someone or something
dictionary.definition: to command that something be received from someone or a group or something; to demand that someone or a group or something do something.  The muggers demanded money from everyone.  The petitioners demanded a response from the board of directors.  She demanded too much of her automobile.

dictionary.phrase: demand something of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to command that something be received from someone or a group or something; to demand that someone or a group or something do something.  The muggers demanded money from everyone.  The petitioners demanded a response from the board of directors.  She demanded too much of her automobile.
to lower someone’s rank from one rank to another. The manager demoted Bill from cashier to clerk. The army demoted her from lieutenant to sergeant.
to lower someone’s rank from one rank to another. The manager demoted Bill from cashier to clerk. The army demoted her from lieutenant to sergeant.

to leave a place, a person, or a situation when things become difficult or unpleasant. (Rats are said to be the first to leave a ship that is sinking.) _ I hate to be the one to desert a sinking ship, but I can’t work for a company that continues to lose money.  There goes Tom. Wouldn’t you know he’d leave a sinking ship rather than stay around and try to help?

dictionary.phrase: develop from someone or something (into someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to grow or evolve out of someone or something into someone or something else. Her interest in music developed from a childlike curiosity to a full-f ledged professional career.  The f lower developed from a little knot of a bulb.

dictionary.phrase: develop (from someone or something) into someone or something

dictionary.phrase: The devil can quote Scripture for his own purpose.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Evil people sometimes try to win the confidence of good people by quoting persuasive passages of Scripture.; Just because someone can quote Scripture to support his or her argument does not mean that the argument is virtuous. (Scripture usually refers to the Bible, but it can refer to other religious writings.) _Sadie: Dad, you really ought to give me permission to go out with Nathan. He’s such a polite boy, and he can even quote the Bible. Father: The devil can quote Scripture for his own purpose.

dictionary.phrase: The devil can cite Scripture for his own purpose.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Evil people sometimes try to win the confidence of good people by quoting persuasive passages of Scripture.; Just because someone can quote Scripture to support his or her argument does not mean that the argument is virtuous. (Scripture usually refers to the Bible, but it can refer to other religious writings.) _Sadie: Dad, you really ought to give me permission to go out with Nathan. He’s such a polite boy, and he can even quote the Bible. Father: The devil can quote Scripture for his own purpose.
the most difficult task.  We had a devil of a job fixing the car.  It was the devil’s own job finding a hotel with vacancies.
the most difficult task.  We had a devil of a job fixing the car.  It was the devil’s own job finding a hotel with vacancies.
a very difficult time. I had a devil of a time with my taxes. This cold has been giving me a devil of a time.  Fixing the car seemed easy, but I had the devil’s own time doing it.
a very difficult time. I had a devil of a time with my taxes. This cold has been giving me a devil of a time.  Fixing the car seemed easy, but I had the devil’s own time doing it.
a very casual attitude; a worry-free or carefree attitude. You must get rid of your devil-may-care attitude if you want to succeed.  She acts so thoughtless—with her devil-may-care manner.
a very casual attitude; a worry-free or carefree attitude. You must get rid of your devil-may-care attitude if you want to succeed.  She acts so thoughtless—with her devil-may-care manner.
constant talking; a “disorder” involving constant talking.  Wow, does he ever have diarrhea of the mouth! _ You’re getting diarrhea of the jawbone again.
constant talking; a “disorder” involving constant talking.  Wow, does he ever have diarrhea of the mouth! _ You’re getting diarrhea of the jawbone again.

to bargain with someone for something; to haggle with someone for something.  I don’t want to stand here dickering with you for a cheap trinket.  I don’t want to waste time dickering with them over a few dollars.

didn’t care at all. Sally thought Joe liked her, but he didn’t care a whit about her.  I don’t care a whit what you do with my old clothes.

to go down fighting; to die in some fashion other than in bed; to die fighting. (Popularized by western movies. Heroes and villains of these movies said they preferred death in a gunfight to showing cowardice or giving up.) _ I won’t let him get me. I’ll die in my boots.

to perish from an injury or a particular disease. The doctors did all they could, but he finally died of cancer. What did it die from?

1. [for someone] to disagree with someone about something. I must differ with you about that.  We differ about that.  I don’t differ with you on that point. 2. [for someone] to argue with someone about something.  Tom was differing with Terry rather loudly about which one of them was going to carry the f lag. Let’s stop differing with each other on these simple things!

to excavate deeply. They are really having to dig deep to reach bedrock.  We are not to the buried cable yet. We will have to dig down some more.

dictionary.phrase: dig someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to excavate in order to get someone or something out of something; to dig about in order to get someone or something out of something.  She dug out the roots of the tree.  The dog dug itself out of the rubble of the fallen building.

to stab or jab something into something. Dig your fork into that heavenly cake! _ He dug in his fork.
to stab or jab something into something. Dig your fork into that heavenly cake! _ He dug in his fork.

to repeat something over and over to someone. (As if one could “hammer” words into someone.) _ The teacher dinned it into her constantly, but it did no good.  He dinned in the same message over and over.

to put something into a substance in order to take some of it.  Tom dipped some of the bread into the cheese sauce.  Dip in the bread again and get some more cheese on it.

to hold views about someone or something that are opposed to someone else’s views.  I take it you disagree with me about Tom.  Don’t disagree about Tom with me.  I disagree about this with almost everyone.  I disagree with you.

becoming sad because of someone or something.  I am really disappointed at what you did.  I am very disappointed in you. That was a terrible thing to do. They were disappointed in the outcome.

dictionary.phrase: disqualify someone or something for something
dictionary.definition: to invalidate someone’s or something’s claim to something. Does being late for practice disqualify me for the team? _ This loss disqualifies our team, doesn’t it? _Does it disqualify us from competition?

dictionary.phrase: disqualify someone or something from something
dictionary.definition: to invalidate someone’s or something’s claim to something. Does being late for practice disqualify me for the team? _ This loss disqualifies our team, doesn’t it? _Does it disqualify us from competition?
to become completely involved with something quickly, especially something new.  I had never done anything like this before, but I just jumped in with both feet and learned it in no time.
to become completely involved with something quickly, especially something new.  I had never done anything like this before, but I just jumped in with both feet and learned it in no time.
to divide something into two equal parts. (The fifty means 50 percent.) _ Tommy and Billy divided the candy fifty-fifty.  The robbers split the money fifty-fifty.
to divide something into two equal parts. (The fifty means 50 percent.) _ Tommy and Billy divided the candy fifty-fifty.  The robbers split the money fifty-fifty.

to give something out in shares to people or groups. (More informal with up. Between with two; among with more.) _ Please divide this up between the visitors.  Cut the birthday cake and divide it up among all the party guests.  Please divide up this pie between the children.

to give something out in shares to people or groups. (More informal with up. Between with two; among with more.) _ Please divide this up between the visitors.  Cut the birthday cake and divide it up among all the party guests.  Please divide up this pie between the children.

to divide something up between two people or among three or more people. (Between is for two and among is for more than two.) _ Would you like to divvy this money up? _ Please divvy up this money between you.  Let’s divvy up the leftovers among all the dinner guests.

to divide something up between two people or among three or more people. (Between is for two and among is for more than two.) _ Would you like to divvy this money up? _ Please divvy up this money between you.  Let’s divvy up the leftovers among all the dinner guests.

to divide something up between two people or among three or more people. (Between is for two and among is for more than two.) _ Would you like to divvy this money up? _ Please divvy up this money between you.  Let’s divvy up the leftovers among all the dinner guests.
to make a total reversal of opinion. Without warning, the government did a f lip-f lop on taxation. The candidate had done an about-face on the question of deductions last year.

1. Lit.to turn around and go in the opposite direction. When I hollered, the dog did a one-eighty and headed back to its own yard. 2. Fig. to radically reverse a decision or opinion. His political philosophy turned one hundred and eighty degrees when he grew a little older.

dictionary.phrase: turn one hundred and eighty degrees
dictionary.definition: 1. Lit.to turn around and go in the opposite direction. When I hollered, the dog did a one-eighty and headed back to its own yard. 2. Fig. to radically reverse a decision or opinion. His political philosophy turned one hundred and eighty degrees when he grew a little older.
to turn completely around. I was really lost. I did a three-sixty in the middle of the street because I couldn’t make up my mind which way to go.
to turn completely around. I was really lost. I did a three-sixty in the middle of the street because I couldn’t make up my mind which way to go.
to add positively to the reputation of someone. Your new job really does credit to you.  Yes, it really does you credit.

to take illegal drugs; to use illegal drugs habitually.  Sam doesn’t do drugs, and he doesn’t drink.  Richard started doing dope when he was very young.

dictionary.phrase: Do I have to spell it out (for you)?
dictionary.definition: What do I have to do to make this clear enough for you to understand? (Shows impatience.) _ Mary: I don’t think I understand what you’re trying to tell me, Fred. Fred: Do I have to spell it out for you? Mary: I guess so. Fred: We’re through, Mary.  Sally: Would you please go over the part about the square root again? Mary: Do I have to paint you a picture? Pay attention!

Fred: Do I have to spell it out for you? Mary: I guess so. Fred: We’re through, Mary.  Sally: Would you please go over the part about the square root again? Mary: Do I have to paint you a picture? dictionary.phrase: Do not let the sun go down on your wrath.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Do not stay angry with anybody; calm your anger by the end of the day.  Son: Billy broke my bicycle, and I’m never going to speak to him again. Mother: Now, now, don’t let the sun go down on your wrath.  I was very upset by what you did, but I don’t want to let the sun go down on my anger. Let’s make up.

Mother: Now, now, don’t let the sun go down on your wrath.  I was very upset by what you did, but I don’t want to let the sun go down on my anger. Let’s make up.
to do one’s share of the work; to do whatever one can do to help. All people everywhere must do their part to conserve energy.  I always try to do my bit. How can I help this time?

to perform a helpful service to someone.  Would you please do me a favor and take this letter to the post office? _ My neighbor did me a good turn by lending me his car.
to perform a helpful service to someone.  Would you please do me a favor and take this letter to the post office? _ My neighbor did me a good turn by lending me his car.

dictionary.phrase: do someone a power of good
dictionary.definition: Rur. to be very good for someone. You should take a vacation. It’d do you a power of good.  Just hearing your voice does me a heap of good.

dictionary.phrase: do someone a heap of good
dictionary.definition: Rur. to be very good for someone. You should take a vacation. It’d do you a power of good.  Just hearing your voice does me a heap of good.
to buy a new wardrobe for someone; to redo someone’s hairstyle, makeup, etc.  Sally’s mother did Sally over for the play tryouts.  The designer made over Sally completely.
to buy a new wardrobe for someone; to redo someone’s hairstyle, makeup, etc.  Sally’s mother did Sally over for the play tryouts.  The designer made over Sally completely.

to do something (despite anything to the contrary). (An emphatic way of saying do.) _Bob: You don’t have your money with you. Bill: I do too! _ He does so! I saw him put it in his pocket. She did too take a cookie. I saw her do it.

to do something (despite anything to the contrary). (An emphatic way of saying do.) _Bob: You don’t have your money with you. Bill: I do too! _ He does so! I saw him put it in his pocket. She did too take a cookie. I saw her do it.

dictionary.phrase: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You should treat other people the way you want them to treat you. (From Luke 6:31; it is also known as “The Golden Rule.”) _Mother: Don’t call your playmates names. Child: Why not? Mother: Because you should follow the Golden Rule: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.  It’s hard to be kind to people sometimes, but I try to remember to do as I’d be done by.

dictionary.phrase: Do as you would be done by.
dictionary.definition: Prov. You should treat other people the way you want them to treat you. (From Luke 6:31; it is also known as “The Golden Rule.”) _Mother: Don’t call your playmates names. Child: Why not? Mother: Because you should follow the Golden Rule: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.  It’s hard to be kind to people sometimes, but I try to remember to do as I’d be done by.

Sl. Do you actually eat with the mouth you use to talk that filth?; Do you actually use that filthy mouth to kiss your mother? (A phrase said to someone who talks dirty all the time.) _ That’s a lot of foul talk. Do you eat with that mouth? _After the suspect finished swearing at him, the police officer said, “Do you kiss your momma with that mouth?”

dictionary.phrase: (Do) you kiss your momma with that mouth?
dictionary.definition: Sl. Do you actually eat with the mouth you use to talk that filth?; Do you actually use that filthy mouth to kiss your mother? (A phrase said to someone who talks dirty all the time.) _ That’s a lot of foul talk. Do you eat with that mouth? _After the suspect finished swearing at him, the police officer said, “Do you kiss your momma with that mouth?”

an expression used to open a conversation or switch to a new topic. Bob: You know what? Mary: No, what? Bob: I think this milk is spoiled.  Bob: Know what? Bill: Tell me. Bob: Your hair needs cutting. Bill: So what?

an expression used to open a conversation or switch to a new topic. Bob: You know what? Mary: No, what? Bob: I think this milk is spoiled.  Bob: Know what? Bill: Tell me. Bob: Your hair needs cutting. Bill: So what?
Do you understand me?; Do you agree? _Sue: This is, like, really great! You know what I’m saying? Mary: Yeah, I’ve been there. It’s great.
Do you understand me?; Do you agree? _Sue: This is, like, really great! You know what I’m saying? Mary: Yeah, I’ve been there. It’s great.
Do you understand me?; Do you agree? _Sue: This is, like, really great! You know what I’m saying? Mary: Yeah, I’ve been there. It’s great.
Do you understand me?; Do you agree? _Sue: This is, like, really great! You know what I’m saying? Mary: Yeah, I’ve been there. It’s great.

Do you really mean to say what you said? (A way of giving someone an opportunity to alter a comment. The something represents a quote or a paraphrase.) _ Mary: I’m leaving tomorrow. Sally: Do you mean to say you’re leaving school for good? Mary: Yes.  Bob: Do you mean to tell me that this is all you’ve accomplished in two weeks? Bill: I guess so. Bob: I expected more.

dictionary.phrase: (Do) you mean to tell me something?
dictionary.definition: Do you really mean to say what you said? (A way of giving someone an opportunity to alter a comment. The something represents a quote or a paraphrase.) _ Mary: I’m leaving tomorrow. Sally: Do you mean to say you’re leaving school for good? Mary: Yes.  Bob: Do you mean to tell me that this is all you’ve accomplished in two weeks? Bill: I guess so. Bob: I expected more.

dictionary.phrase: (Do you) want to make something of it?
dictionary.definition: Do you want to start a fight about it? (Rude and contentious.) _ Tom: You’re really bugging me. It’s not fair to pick on me all the time. Bill: You want to make something of it? _ Bob: Please be quiet. You’re making too much noise. Fred: Do you want to make something of it?

dictionary.phrase: You want to make something of it?
dictionary.definition: Do you want to start a fight about it? (Rude and contentious.) _ Tom: You’re really bugging me. It’s not fair to pick on me all the time. Bill: You want to make something of it? _ Bob: Please be quiet. You’re making too much noise. Fred: Do you want to make something of it?

dictionary.phrase: doesn’t have enough sense to bell a cat
dictionary.definition: acts foolish. (Also with don’t. Don’t used with all persons is folksy.) _ I should’ve known Mary would mess things up completely. She doesn’t have enough sense to bell a cat. Look after Joe and make sure he doesn’t get into trouble. You know he doesn’t have enough sense to bell a cat. I ain’t surprised that Jim spends a hundred dollars a week on the lottery. Everyone knows he don’t have enough sense to come in out of the rain.

dictionary.phrase: doesn’t have enough sense to come in out of the rain
dictionary.definition: acts foolish. (Also with don’t. Don’t used with all persons is folksy.) _ I should’ve known Mary would mess things up completely. She doesn’t have enough sense to bell a cat. Look after Joe and make sure he doesn’t get into trouble. You know he doesn’t have enough sense to bell a cat. I ain’t surprised that Jim spends a hundred dollars a week on the lottery. Everyone knows he don’t have enough sense to come in out of the rain.

dictionary.phrase: doesn’t have the sense God gave geese
dictionary.definition: Prov. Doesn’t have basic common sense. (Also with don’t. Don’t used with all persons is folksy.) _ Mary’s going out in this incredibly cold weather without a hat or gloves. She doesn’t have the sense God gave geese. It was obvious that the man was a swindler, but George gave him all his money anyway. I swear, George doesn’t have the sense God gave him.

dictionary.phrase: doesn’t have the sense God gave him (or her)
dictionary.definition: Prov. Doesn’t have basic common sense. (Also with don’t. Don’t used with all persons is folksy.) _ Mary’s going out in this incredibly cold weather without a hat or gloves. She doesn’t have the sense God gave geese. It was obvious that the man was a swindler, but George gave him all his money anyway. I swear, George doesn’t have the sense God gave him.

dictionary.phrase: doesn’t know his ass from a hole in the ground
dictionary.definition: doesn’t know anything; acts ignorant. (Use ass with caution. Also with don’t. Don’t used with all persons is folksy.) _ That teacher doesn’t know his ass from a hole in the ground.  She’s supposed to be an expert, but she doesn’t know her ass from her elbow.

dictionary.phrase: doesn’t know his ass from his elbow
dictionary.definition: doesn’t know anything; acts ignorant. (Use ass with caution. Also with don’t. Don’t used with all persons is folksy.) _ That teacher doesn’t know his ass from a hole in the ground.  She’s supposed to be an expert, but she doesn’t know her ass from her elbow.

illusory; purposefully deceptive. The whole legislative budgetary process is done with mirrors. The company’s self-review was done by mirrors and didn’t come off too bad, despite our falling stock price.

illusory; purposefully deceptive. The whole legislative budgetary process is done with mirrors. The company’s self-review was done by mirrors and didn’t come off too bad, despite our falling stock price.
Don’t tell me those lies! _ Don’t give me that line! I know the truth! You’re lying to me!
Don’t tell me those lies! _ Don’t give me that line! I know the truth! You’re lying to me!

dictionary.phrase: Don’t judge a book by its cover.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Do not draw a conclusion about someone or something just from outward appearances.  Just because Sam dresses sloppy doesn’t mean he’s a bad person. Don’t judge a book by its cover.  Jill: How can you be so sure this will be a boring movie? Jane: The poster for it is so boring. Jill: Don’t judge a book by its cover!

dictionary.phrase: You can’t tell a book by its cover.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Do not draw a conclusion about someone or something just from outward appearances.  Just because Sam dresses sloppy doesn’t mean he’s a bad person. Don’t judge a book by its cover.  Jill: How can you be so sure this will be a boring movie? Jane: The poster for it is so boring. Jill: Don’t judge a book by its cover!

dictionary.phrase: Don’t let it go any further.
dictionary.definition: Don’t tell this secret to anyone else. (Also literal.) _ This is a strict secret. Don’t let it go any further. I’ll tell you what you what to know, but don’t let it go out of this room.

dictionary.phrase: Don’t let it out of this room.
dictionary.definition: Don’t tell this secret to anyone else. (Also literal.) _ This is a strict secret. Don’t let it go any further. I’ll tell you what you what to know, but don’t let it go out of this room.

dictionary.phrase: Don’t make me say it again!
dictionary.definition: I have told you once, and now I’m mad, and I’ll be madder if I have to tell you again. (Typically said to a child who will not obey.) _ Mother: I told you thirty minutes ago to clean up this room! Don’t make me tell you again!

dictionary.phrase: Don’t make me tell you again!
dictionary.definition: I have told you once, and now I’m mad, and I’ll be madder if I have to tell you again. (Typically said to a child who will not obey.) _ Mother: I told you thirty minutes ago to clean up this room! Don’t make me tell you again!

Don’t quit your regular job in hopes that you can support yourself doing this task that you do not do very well.  I saw your comedy act at the nightclub. Don’t quit your day job! _ So, you laid the bricks in this wall. Well, don’t quit your day job.

dictionary.phrase: Don’t give up your day job.
dictionary.definition: Don’t quit your regular job in hopes that you can support yourself doing this task that you do not do very well.  I saw your comedy act at the nightclub. Don’t quit your day job! _ So, you laid the bricks in this wall. Well, don’t quit your day job.

Rur. a short distance down the road. Smith’s Dry Goods Store? It’s down the road a piece, on the left-hand side.  I’m not sure we’re lost. Let’s go on down the road a stretch and see if we recognize anything.

Rur. a short distance down the road. Smith’s Dry Goods Store? It’s down the road a piece, on the left-hand side.  I’m not sure we’re lost. Let’s go on down the road a stretch and see if we recognize anything.
to go on slowly for a very long time; to last a very long time.  The lecture dragged on and on.  Why do these things have to drag on so? _ How much longer do you think his speech will drag out?
to go on slowly for a very long time; to last a very long time.  The lecture dragged on and on.  Why do these things have to drag on so? _ How much longer do you think his speech will drag out?

dictionary.phrase: drag one’s feet (on or over something)
dictionary.definition: to progress slowly or stall in the doing of something.  Why is she taking so long? I think she is just dragging her feet on this matter.  I didn’t mean to drag my feet on this decision.  If the planning department had not dragged their heels, the building would have been built by now. You must not drag your heels over this; we must get finished.

dictionary.phrase: drag one’s heels (on or over something)
dictionary.definition: to progress slowly or stall in the doing of something.  Why is she taking so long? I think she is just dragging her feet on this matter.  I didn’t mean to drag my feet on this decision.  If the planning department had not dragged their heels, the building would have been built by now. You must not drag your heels over this; we must get finished.

dictionary.phrase: drag someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to haul or pull someone or something into something or some place.  She dragged in the child to make him put on this jacket.  Despite his broken leg, he dragged himself into the shelter.
to haul or pull someone or something into something or some place.  She dragged in the child to make him put on this jacket.  Despite his broken leg, he dragged himself into the shelter.

dictionary.phrase: drag someone or something off of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to pull or remove someone or something off someone or something. (The of is informal.) _The police officers dragged the boys off the top of the wall.  The cops dragged off the boys and took them home.

to pull or remove someone or something off someone or something. (The of is informal.) _The police officers dragged the boys off the top of the wall.  The cops dragged off the boys and took them home.

dictionary.phrase: drag someone or something on(to) something
dictionary.definition: to pull or lead someone or something to a particular place, such as a stage, platform, dance floor, etc. The master of ceremonies dragged her onto the stage for another bow. Then he dragged on the next performer.

to pull or lead someone or something to a particular place, such as a stage, platform, dance floor, etc. The master of ceremonies dragged her onto the stage for another bow. Then he dragged on the next performer.

dictionary.phrase: drag someone or something over to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to pull or haul someone or something to someone or something. He dragged the chair over to the window so he could sit and watch the children.  Drag over a chair and sit down.
to pull or haul someone or something to someone or something. He dragged the chair over to the window so he could sit and watch the children.  Drag over a chair and sit down.

to push or pull something away from something or some place.  He dragged the sofa away from the wall so he could clean behind it. He had to drag away the sofa in order to plug in the lamp.  We worked together to drag it away.

to push or pull something away from something or some place.  He dragged the sofa away from the wall so he could clean behind it. He had to drag away the sofa in order to plug in the lamp.  We worked together to drag it away.

to force someone to reveal something; to extract an answer or information out of someone laboriously.  Why don’t you just tell me? Do I have to drag it out of you? _ We had to drag out the information, but she finally told us.

to force someone to reveal something; to extract an answer or information out of someone laboriously.  Why don’t you just tell me? Do I have to drag it out of you? _ We had to drag out the information, but she finally told us.
to cause or permit something to flow from the surface or contents of something.  Drain some of the broth off the chicken.  Drain off the fat at the bottom of the pan.
to cause or permit something to flow from the surface or contents of something.  Drain some of the broth off the chicken.  Drain off the fat at the bottom of the pan.
to cause something to flow from something; to empty all of some liquid out of something.  She drained the last drop out of the bottle. She drained out all the water in the pot.
to cause something to flow from something; to empty all of some liquid out of something.  She drained the last drop out of the bottle. She drained out all the water in the pot.

dictionary.phrase: draw a bead on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to locate someone or something in the sights of a gun.  Fred drew a bead on the target and pulled the trigger. The hunter drew a bead on the deer.

dictionary.phrase: get a bead on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to locate someone or something in the sights of a gun.  Fred drew a bead on the target and pulled the trigger. The hunter drew a bead on the deer.

dictionary.phrase: draw a line between something and something else
dictionary.definition: to separate two things; to distinguish or differentiate between two things. (Also with the.) _ I draw a line between just bumping into people and actually striking them.  It’s very hard to draw a line between slamming a door and just closing it loudly.

dictionary.phrase: draw the line between something and something else
dictionary.definition: to separate two things; to distinguish or differentiate between two things. (Also with the.) _ I draw a line between just bumping into people and actually striking them.  It’s very hard to draw a line between slamming a door and just closing it loudly.
to pull back or away from someone or something.  Don’t draw apart from the rest of us.  Please don’t draw away from me. I won’t bite.  She drew away slowly and left the room.
to pull back or away from someone or something.  Don’t draw apart from the rest of us.  Please don’t draw away from me. I won’t bite.  She drew away slowly and left the room.

to choose lots for something, without looking; to draw a token for something from a set of tokens concealed in something. (The tokens are typically slips of paper, one of which is marked as the winner. See also draw straws.) _Let’s draw for the prize. The winner gets it.  We will draw for a winner from the five finalists.  The players drew lots to determine who would go first.

to choose lots for something, without looking; to draw a token for something from a set of tokens concealed in something. (The tokens are typically slips of paper, one of which is marked as the winner. See also draw straws.) _Let’s draw for the prize. The winner gets it.  We will draw for a winner from the five finalists.  The players drew lots to determine who would go first.
to back down from a fight. For a minute it looked like they were gonna start sluggin’ each other, but then they drew in their horns. We tried to calm him down and get him to pull in his horns.
to back down from a fight. For a minute it looked like they were gonna start sluggin’ each other, but then they drew in their horns. We tried to calm him down and get him to pull in his horns.

to use someone or something in some beneficial way; to extract from a resource, reserve, etc. I may have to draw on your advice in order to complete this project.  If there is some way you can draw on me to your advantage, let me know.  By the end of the contest I had drawn upon all the energy I had.

to use someone or something in some beneficial way; to extract from a resource, reserve, etc. I may have to draw on your advice in order to complete this project.  If there is some way you can draw on me to your advantage, let me know.  By the end of the contest I had drawn upon all the energy I had.

dictionary.phrase: draw someone or an animal out of something
dictionary.definition: to lure someone or an animal out of something or some place.  I thought the smell of breakfast would draw him out of his slumber. The catnip drew out the cat from under the front porch.

dictionary.phrase: draw someone or an animal out†
dictionary.definition: to lure someone or an animal out of something or some place.  I thought the smell of breakfast would draw him out of his slumber. The catnip drew out the cat from under the front porch.

dictionary.phrase: draw someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to pull someone or something into something; to attract someone or something in.  She drew the child into the shoe store and plunked her down.  Liz opened the door and drew in the children who were all bundled in their parkas.

to pull someone or something into something; to attract someone or something in.  She drew the child into the shoe store and plunked her down.  Liz opened the door and drew in the children who were all bundled in their parkas.

dictionary.phrase: draw someone or something out of some place
dictionary.definition: to pull someone or something out of a place. We drew him out of the crawl space where he lay hiding.  We drew the concealed microphone out of the cabinet.
to pull someone or something out of a place. We drew him out of the crawl space where he lay hiding.  We drew the concealed microphone out of the cabinet.

dictionary.phrase: draw someone out on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to bring out someone’s private thoughts about someone or something.  I tried to draw him out on this matter, but he would not say any more.  I tried to draw out the speaker, but she would not elaborate on what she had said.  Fred wanted to draw out information about the company’s plans, but the controller had nothing to say.

dictionary.phrase: draw someone out about someone or something
dictionary.definition: to bring out someone’s private thoughts about someone or something.  I tried to draw him out on this matter, but he would not say any more.  I tried to draw out the speaker, but she would not elaborate on what she had said.  Fred wanted to draw out information about the company’s plans, but the controller had nothing to say.

to bring out someone’s private thoughts about someone or something.  I tried to draw him out on this matter, but he would not say any more.  I tried to draw out the speaker, but she would not elaborate on what she had said.  Fred wanted to draw out information about the company’s plans, but the controller had nothing to say.

dictionary.phrase: draw (someone’s) fire (away) from someone, something, or an animal
dictionary.definition: to attract the attention of someone firing a gun away from the target, hoping to protect the target; to make oneself a target in order to protect someone or something. (Can be verbal “fire,” such as questions, etc.) _The mother bird drew fire away from her chicks. The hen drew away the hunter’s fire.  The president drew fire away from Congress by proposing a compromise.

to attract the attention of someone firing a gun away from the target, hoping to protect the target; to make oneself a target in order to protect someone or something. (Can be verbal “fire,” such as questions, etc.) _The mother bird drew fire away from her chicks. The hen drew away the hunter’s fire.  The president drew fire away from Congress by proposing a compromise.
to get some kind of information from someone. He kept his mouth closed, and we couldn’t draw anything out of him.  We were able to draw out the information we wanted.
to get some kind of information from someone. He kept his mouth closed, and we couldn’t draw anything out of him.  We were able to draw out the information we wanted.
to move up even with someone or something in motion.  The police officer drew up alongside us and ordered us to pull over.  A car drew up alongside us.
to move up even with someone or something in motion.  The police officer drew up alongside us and ordered us to pull over.  A car drew up alongside us.
to have mental pictures about someone or something, especially in one’s sleep. I dreamed about you all night last night.  I dreamed of a huge chocolate cake.
to have mental pictures about someone or something, especially in one’s sleep. I dreamed about you all night last night.  I dreamed of a huge chocolate cake.

dictionary.phrase: Dream of a funeral and you hear of a marriage.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you dream that a person has died, you will learn that person is to be married.  Alan: I had a dream last night that my sister was killed. Jane: Dream of a funeral and you hear of a marriage.

dictionary.phrase: Dream of a funeral and you hear of a wedding.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you dream that a person has died, you will learn that person is to be married.  Alan: I had a dream last night that my sister was killed. Jane: Dream of a funeral and you hear of a marriage.

dictionary.phrase: drench someone or something in something
dictionary.definition: to soak someone or something in something.  A sudden summer shower drenched them in sheets of rain.  My raincoat was drenched with droplets from the foggy night air.

dictionary.phrase: drench someone or something with something
dictionary.definition: to soak someone or something in something.  A sudden summer shower drenched them in sheets of rain.  My raincoat was drenched with droplets from the foggy night air.

dressed in fancy or stylish clothes. fit to kill.) _ Wow, look at Sally! She’s really dressed to kill.  A person doesn’t go on vacation dressed to kill.  When Joe came to pick Mary up for the movie, he was dressed up fit to kill and carrying a dozen roses.

dressed in fancy or stylish clothes. fit to kill.) _ Wow, look at Sally! She’s really dressed to kill.  A person doesn’t go on vacation dressed to kill.  When Joe came to pick Mary up for the movie, he was dressed up fit to kill and carrying a dozen roses.
dressed very stylishly with nothing overlooked.  She showed up for the picnic dressed to the nines. Clare is usually dressed to the teeth in order to impress people.
dressed very stylishly with nothing overlooked.  She showed up for the picnic dressed to the nines. Clare is usually dressed to the teeth in order to impress people.

dictionary.phrase: drill something into someone or something
dictionary.definition: to force knowledge into someone or something.  Learn this stuff! Drill it into your brain.  Drill in this information so you know it by heart!
to force knowledge into someone or something.  Learn this stuff! Drill it into your brain.  Drill in this information so you know it by heart!
to make something fall into something drop by drop. Alice dripped a little candle wax into the base of the candlestick.  Don’t pour it all into the jar. Drip in a little at a time.
to make something fall into something drop by drop. Alice dripped a little candle wax into the base of the candlestick.  Don’t pour it all into the jar. Drip in a little at a time.
to force the price of something upwards.  Someone is buying a lot of gold and driving the price up.  They are driving up the price.
to force the price of something upwards.  Someone is buying a lot of gold and driving the price up.  They are driving up the price.
to annoy or irritate someone.  You are certainly annoying! You’re going to drive me batty.  This cold is driving me bonkers. These tax forms are driving me nuts.
